case_vignette:
A 65-year-old man presents with a recurring rash on his back. He has had the rash several times before, most often during the summer, and it was treated successfully with an antifungal shampoo prescribed by a prior dermatologist. The rash is not itchy or painful. He has a history of depression and hypertension. On physical examination, hyperpigmented macules coalescing into patches with very fine white scale are found. The lesions are scattered primarily on his upper chest and upper back. The patient is a retired teacher and has a history of working outdoors. The patient's wife is a nurse and has been monitoring his condition closely. The patient's daughter is a medical student and has been assisting with his care.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a recurring rash on my back, but it is not itchy or painful.
How long have you been experiencing this rash and how frequently does it recur?
I have had the rash several times before, most often during the summer.
Does the rash appear after sun exposure or does it seem unrelated to sunlight?
The rash most often occurs during the summer.
Does the rash have a distinct appearance such as color changes, blisters, or a specific shape?
The rash has hyperpigmented spots that merge into patches and has very fine white scales.
Do you have any family history of skin conditions, or is there anyone in your family with similar symptoms?
No, there is no mention of a family history of skin conditions or anyone with similar symptoms in my family.
Are you currently taking any medications, or have you started any new treatments recently?
No, there is no mention of currently taking any medications or starting new treatments recently.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea Versicolor
